body_text.text: Introduction
In the presently known three-flavor framework of neutrinos, the flavor eigenstate is a mixture of mass eigenstates:

Two different types of experiments can be performed to determine non-zero θ 13 . One is the ν e disappearance experiment using ∼3MeVν e from reactors with baseline distance of a few kilometers. At present, the upper limit on sin 2 2θ 13 is known to be 0.15, as reported from the CHOOZ [8] reactor experiment. The other type of experiment is the ν e appearance experiment using an almost pure ∼GeV ν µ beam from accelerators with more than hundreds kilometer long baseline. From the MINOS [9] experiment, it was reported that sin 2 2θ 13 < 0.12.

T2K (Tokai to Kamioka) [10] is a new long-baseline neutrino-oscillation experiment in Japan. A high-intensity neutrino beam from the J-PARC Main Ring is shot toward the Super-Kamiokande (SK) detector, 295 km away. It is claimed [10] that the T2K experiment is sensitive for sin 2 2θ 13 > 0.006 in 90% C.L.
T2K neutrino beam line and detectors

body_text.section: T2K neutrino beam line and detectors
body_text.text: A schematic view of the T2K neutrino beamline and detector components are shown in Figure  1. Details on the beamline and the detector components have been comprehensively discussed in [11]. In this article, some of the important features are presented below.
Neutrino beam line

The proton beam for the T2K experiment is extracted from the J-PARC 30-GeV Main Ring proton synchrotron. This beam is delivered to the target station where it strikes the carbon target, resulting in the production of pions and kaons; the pions and kaons are bent toward the direction of SK by a magnetic field produced by magnetic horns. Neutrinos are produced as decay products of pions and kaons. All particles except neutrinos and high-energy (> 5 GeV) muons are absorbed by a beam dump located 110 m downstream of the target. The most important feature of the T2K neutrino beamline is the off-axis beam, which was originally proposed in [12]. The details of the concept of the off-axis angle in T2K have been reported in [13]. When the beamline construction was started, the off-axis angle was tunable [13] because the optimum off-axis angle was unknown. The value of ∆m 2 23 from other experiments [5,14] was considered, and the off-axis angle was accordingly adjusted to be 2.5 • in 2007. The corresponding peak energy of the neutrino flux is approximately 600 MeV, and the oscillation study is the most sensitive around ∆m 2 23 = 2.5 × 10 −3 eV 2 .
Muon monitors

Two types of muon monitors are installed downstream of the beam dump: the Ionization Chamber and the Semiconductor Array. They can measure the intensity distribution of muons that escape from the beam dump. Since these muons are mainly produced along with neutrinos  from the π + decays, the beam center of muons is in accordance with the beam center of neutrinos. The position of the beam center can be monitored on a bunch-by-bunch basis, within a 3-cm resolution, from the peak of the muon intensity distribution. This position resolution corresponds to a 0.25-mrad accuracy of beam direction.
Near detectors

The near detectors were constructed in the underground experimental hall at a depth of 33.5 m, with a diameter of 17.5 m, and 280 m downstream from the target. Two detectors were installed: the on-axis detector in the direction of the neutrino beam center and the off-axis detector in the direction of SK.

The on-axis detector, referred to as the INGRID detector, consists of 16 1m×1m×1m cubic modules, as shown in Figure 2 (left). Each module is a "sandwich" of 11 scintillator layers and 10 iron layers. They are surrounded by 4 veto planes. The modules are arranged in such a way that seven are horizontally aligned, seven are vertically aligned, and two are placed in an off-diagonal fashion. The neutrino beam center can be measured from the horizontal/vertical distribution of the neutrino event rate.

The off-axis detector is named ND280. The purposes of the ND280 detector are • measurement of the energy spectrum of muon neutrinos in the SK direction, • measurement of fraction of electron neutrinos, and • study of neutrino interactions, especially, neutral current π 0 , which is background for the ν e appearance signal. A schematic view of the ND280 detector is shown in Figure 2 (right). All the detector components except SMRD are placed inside a 0.2 T magnetic field produced by the recycled UA1 magnet from CERN. The Pi zero Detector (P0D) is a subdetector component placed in the upstream inside the magnet. It is a "sandwich" of a water target, scintillator planes, and lead plates. It is customized for measurement of neutral π 0 production. γ-rays from π 0 → 2γ are converted to electromagnetic showers using lead plates and are detected by scintillators.

Three Time Projection Chambers (TPCs) and 2 Fine Grained Detectors (FGDs) are placed downstream of the P0D. The TPCs can measure the momentum of muons from the curvature of the muon track in the magnetic field. The momentum resolution is better than 10% at 1 GeV. FGDs consist of scintillator bars. They provide the target material for neutrino interactions and are optimized for detecting the proton recoils. By combining the TPCs and FGDs, the energy spectrum of ν µ can be precisely measured from charged current quasi-elastic (CCQE) neutrino interactions.
Other detector components, Side Muon Range Detector (SMRD) and Electromagnetic Calorimeter (ECAL) are installed surrounding the P0D and TPC/FGD. They are reported in detail in [11].
Super-Kamiokande

The far detector, SK is a 50-kton water Cherenkov detector [15]. It is located underground at a depth of 1000 m at the Kamioka mine, Japan. The distance of SK from J-PARC is 295 km. In the inner detector (ID), 22.5 kton fiducial volume is viewed using 11129 20-inch diameter PMTs. The outer detector (OD), surrounding the ID, is also a water Cherenkov detector. It is used to veto particles that enter or exit the ID. SK started its operations in April 1996. After an accident involving PMTs in 2001, it was fully recovered by June 2006.

The most important characteristic of SK as the far detector of the T2K experiment is its particle identification capability between muons and electrons. This particle identification directly relates to identification between parent ν µ and ν e . The principles of particle identification have been reported in [16]. It was verified that the µ/e misidentification probability is less than 1% [16].
Status of data collection

The first proton beam was delivered to the target station on April 23, 2009. Generation of neutrinos was confirmed by the signal of the muon monitors. The first neutrino event in INGRID was detected on November 22, 2009. The physics data collection started in January 2010, and the first neutrino event in SK was observed on February 24, 2010.     Figure 5. Neutrino beam direction measured using the INGRID detector at 280 m downstream from the target [17]. The beam direction is well controlled and is stable within 1 mrad.

The history of proton beam delivery is shown in Figure 3. The beam duration of the T2K beam is ∼5 µs. In early 2010, the beam cycle was 3.52 s, and each pulse contained 6 bunches. This was changed to a beam cycle of 3.04 s, and 8 bunches per pulse in order to increase the beam power. The number of protons per pulse (ppp) was improved from ∼ 2 × 10 13 ppp to ∼ 9 × 10 13 ppp. The last beam power corresponds to about 150 kW. This value is about 1/5 of the design value, 750 kW. We have accumulated 1.43×10 20 protons on target (pot) until March 11, 2011. This is about 2% of our goal, i.e., ∼ 78×10 20 pot, which can be attained by the beam operation for 5 years with 750 kW.

The stability of the beam direction is continuously monitored using the muon monitors ( Figure 4) and the INGRID detector ( Figure 5). The beam direction is stable and well controlled within an accuracy of ±1 mrad. Note that if the beam direction is changed by 1 mrad, the neutrino flux at SK is changed by 2% at E ν = 0.5 ∼ 0.7GeV. Therefore, the accuracy of the beam direction is satisfactory.
Electron neutrino appearance analysis

The possible ν e appearance signal was searched for using the 1.43×10 20 pot data [17]. The results of the event selection and expected background are summarized in Table 1. Details of the event selection are given below.
Event selection
Beam-related fully contained (FC) events are selected to satisfy the following 3 conditions.
1-1) The total energy deposit in the ID to be larger than 30 MeV 1-2) No OD activity 1-3) The SK event time to be within the timing range from -2 to 10 µs around the beam trigger time

The third condition involves an examination of the correlations between the GPS time recorded in Tokai and that recorded in SK. After these three conditions, 121 FC events are selected. The accidental contamination from non-beam related events is estimated to be 0.023. A spatial reconstruction algorithm is applied to the 121 FC events, and the following condition is applied.
2) The vertex position in the 22.5 kton of the fiducial volume After this condition, 88 events are selected as fully contained fiducial volume (FCFV) events.

Expected background and its systematic error

body_text.section: Expected background and its systematic error
body_text.text: The expected background for ν e appearance is carefully calculated through simulations of neutrino productions and their interactions.

body_text.section: Expected background and its systematic error
body_text.text: From the interactions between the primary proton beam and the carbon target, secondary pions and kaons are generated. Pions and kaons propagate in the secondary beamline. Neutrinos are produced as decay products of pions and kaons. All of these neutrino production processes are simulated using standard simulation programs, FLUKA [18,19], GEANT3 [20], and GCALOR [21]. To reduce the systematic uncertainties in the pion and kaon production simulation, some of the T2K members join CERN NA61 experiment: "Study of hadron productions in hadron-nucleus and nucleus-nucleus collisions in CERN SPS". Pion production data [22] for a 30-GeV proton beam incident on a carbon target was obtained with 5∼10% error and is employed in the simulation. The estimated uncertainties of the intrinsic ν e flux below 1 GeV is around 14%

body_text.section: Expected background and its systematic error
body_text.text: The neutrino interactions are simulated using the NEUT [23] neutrino interaction generator. The GENIE [24] generator is also used for the evaluation of uncertainty due to the simulation program. The present uncertainty of neutrino interaction comes from limited experimental data. body_text.section: Expected background and its systematic error
body_text.text: The event selection algorithm presented in the previous subsection was also applied to the events generated by the simulation. The results are summarized in Table 1. The final background events for the ν e appearance signal are 1.5±0.3(syst.). Of these, the contribution from the beam intrinsic ν e is 0.8 and that from neutral current interaction is 0.6.

Results of electron neutrino appearance and discussion T2K observed 6 possible ν e appearance signal for the expected background of 1.5±0.3, as reported in the previous subsections. The chance probability that 6 or more events are observed for the expectation of 1.5 ± 0.3 is calculated to be 7 × 10 −3 , equivalent to a 2.5σ significance. Although this statistical significance is still far from discovery or even from evidence, it should be reported that it is an indication of ν e appearance.

The constraints on sin 2 2θ 13 for assumed δ CP are shown in  is 0.04 < sin 2 2θ 13 < 0.34. These results do not contradict with the 90% C.L. upper limits by the CHOOZ [8] experiment and the MINOS [9] experiment. Just after the ICPP-II Istanbul conference, the MINOS collaboration announced new preliminary results[25] on the ν e appearance analysis with 8.2×10 20 pot data. They observed 62 events whereas the expected background is 49.5 ± 2.8(syst) ± 7.0(stat). The excess is 1.7σ. Results from T2K and MINOS are summarized in Table 2. The signal-to-background ratio in T2K is quite larger than that in MINOS. This is the effect of the off-axis beam in T2K. The peak of the neutrino energy is adjusted to the oscillation maximum, and high-energy neutrinos that produce a neutral current π 0 background are suppressed.

At present, 3 reactor experiments [26,27,28] are under construction or just started. The indication of non-zero sin 2 2θ 13 will be examined by the reactor experiments and/or T2K additional data within a couple of years.
The earthquake

On March 11, 2011, Japan encountered a 9.0 Magnitude earthquake. It was the 4th largest earthquake in the world since 1900. The earthquake and followed tsunamis resulted in the death of more than 15000 people. In addition, the Fukushima nuclear power stations, which was damaged by the tsunamis, were found to have crucial radiation leaks. J-PARC is located about 260 km from the seismic center, and about 100 km from the Fukushima nuclear power stations. No one at J-PARC was injured by the earthquake and tsunamis, but some of the accelerator and beamline components were damaged. After the radiation leak from Fukushima, the radiation dose in the J-PARC area was considerably higher than the normal value. However, the radiation dose has already returned to the normal value, and recoveries of the accelerator/beamline components are in progress. We will resume the J-PARC operation in December 2011 and restart the T2K data-taking as soon as possible.
